The History of Russian Immigrants in the United States

Creator: Hine, Lewis Wickes

Title: [Beet workers, ten years, twelve years, fourteen years and eighteen years, hoeing for father, Jacob Dill, in Sugar City, Colorado. They moved here ten years ago from Southern Russia, work all summer and after the topping is over in the fall they go to school. See Hine Report, Colorado Beet Workers, July, 1915.] Location: [Sugar City, Colorado].

Date: 1915 July

Format: Photograph

Institution: National Child Labor Committee

Link: https://www.loc.gov/resource/nclc.00265/

Russians began migrating to the United States during the late 19th century. Many Russians were facing land shortages, poverty, and starvation back home in the Russian farmlands and this was a primary factor to their migration to the United States. Unfortunately, for the Russians who didnâ€™t come from the countryside, they were barred from leaving the country due to their imperial government. For the Russians who were successful in moving to the United States. They began to form their own communities while taking work when it presented itself. Many of the new Russian settlers also made use of the Homestead Act, where they began moving out west to start their own family farms. Many pacifist sects, also known as Dukhobors and Molokans, established themselves in California and Oregon. Numerous Russian immigrants began working in expanding sectors in the American economy. These jobs included mining, mill factories, and sweatshops based out of the East Coast and Great Lakes.
